Pyjama wearing neighbours from hell told to start behaving or lose their homes Purge targeted a total of 13 households over offences including racial harassment, assaulting a police officer, being drunk and disorderly, burglary and shoplifting   Share   Comments By SONIA SHARMA Marc Walker 08:44, 16 FEB 2017 Updated 09:23, 16 FEB 2017 News Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next Two men brawl outside takeaway in the Gay Village Watch this video again Watch Next Terrifying moment car drives wrong way down busy 0:29 Masked robber leaves bookmakers terrified in claw 1:18 62-year-old Brit caught in bed with prostitute as 1:12 Netflix announce date of Anne of Green Gables reb 0:36 How to be a good dancer 0:44 The World of Pokémon GO has Expanded With the lat 0:39 Idiot driver risks his life swerving around barri 0:28 Video will play in  Neighbours told clean up or clear off in early morning raids Share this video Watch Next     daily   Neighbours from hell dressed in pyjamas and dressing gowns are told to start behaving or lose their homes in early morning raids.
The 7am purge targeted a total of 13 households over offences including racial harassment, assaulting a police officer, being drunk and disorderly, burglary and shoplifting.
Council officers, backed by Northumbria Police , issued notices to the families in North Shields, Tyne and Wear, which are all associated with crime and antisocial behaviour. 
Unrepentant residents face eviction from their homes and could even face being barred from the entering their housing estate, reports ChronicleLive. 
Northumbria Police and Colin Boxshall from North Tyneside Council serve notices to neighbours from hell (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Read More Neighbour from hell who called mum 'white trash' loses appeal after Jeremy Kyle Show attack used as evidence One of the properties was visited after six me were arrested for a punch-up at a house party there in December.
A female tenant came to the door and was warned that legal action could be taken against her as a result of the disturbance.
Elsewhere, two women were told eviction proceedings would start against them as one of their family members had been jointly charged with aggravated burglary.
And a man was visited due to his involvement in a wounding incident.
The early morning raids were carried out in North Shields (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Read More Family's home destroyed by 'boisterous' Boxer dog after illegal puppy trader told them it was more placid breed The early morning wake-up calls were part of Operation Respect – a joint initiative between North Tyneside Council and police.
Colin Boxshall, manager of the community and public spaces protection team, said: “Fortunately antisocial behaviour in North Tyneside is not widespread but where it does occur it can have an enormous impact on people’s lives.
“Our management of antisocial behaviour cases demonstrates a clear focus on protecting people from harm and on supporting victims and witnesses.
Police keep a careful watch while the notices are issued to troublesome households (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) “People risk losing their home or face being excluded from entering housing estates if they continue to engage in crime or antisocial behaviour after receiving a warning.
“We make full use of antisocial behaviour legislation which includes issuing perpetrators with community protection notices, fixed penalty fines, eviction orders and injunctions.
“Repeat offenders risk court orders that will prevent them from entering North Tyneside.
“There are no hiding places for perpetrators. North Tyneside is a great place to live, work and visit, and in partnership with the police our resolve is to keep it that way.”
Residents guilty of antisocial behaviour face eviction if they continue to blight their community (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) As well as speaking to perpetrators, the team delivered letters to neighbouring residents advising them of the action taken and encouraging them to report any further anti-social behaviour they witness.
Acting Inspector Guy Morgan said: “Antisocial behaviour is an issue that law Northumbria Police takes very seriously due to the major impact it can have on individuals and communities. Working with the community protection team, North Tyneside Council and other partners, we aim to protect our communities.
“Operation Respect allows us to pro-actively deal with tenants who cause problems within the community.
“Tenants need to realise the impact of their behaviour on others and understand that they could risk losing their homes if they act in an antisocial way. The joint visits we carried out should serve as a warning that we will take swift action against anyone who continues to engage in antisocial behaviour.”
